rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Agapanthus africanus
rdf:Description.ns5:abstract: Agapanthus africanus, or the African lily, is a flowering plant from the genus Agapanthus found only on rocky sandstone slopes of the winter rainfall fynbos from the Cape Peninsula to Swellendam. It is also known as the lily-of-the-Nile in spite of only occurring in South Africa.
rdf:Description.ns3:ecology:
Pollination is by wind, bees and sunbirds and seed dispersal by the wind. Chacma baboons and buck
sometimes eat the flower heads just as the first flowers begin to open. These plants are adapted to survive fire in the fynbos and resprout from thick, fleshy roots after fire has passed through the area.
bees sunbirds Chacma baboons
